Beginning with the 20.10 release, all Blue Planet products require the use of a license server. Be sure to include this requirement in your hardware plans, and follow the instructions in this guide to ensure you set up and use the license server.

This guide provides procedures to install the 5G Network Slicing Intelligent Automation Solution platform and solutions in a single-host or multi-host deployment on any of the following operating systems:

5G Network Slicing IAS is comprised of many individual solutions that run in an RHEL environment. To succeed, specific OS-level configurations are required including many that require root access. 5G Network Slicing IAS installation is more than a simple application installation. To ensure a successful installation and functional application, review the following guidelines and OS configuration requirements before you begin installation:

You must complete all RHEL and CentOS installations from the base ISO DVD image. All OS installations must have the Infrastructure Server package installed simultaneously with the OS image. Installing the Infrastructure Server package based on updated OS repositories is not supported.

5G Network Slicing IAS has been verified against specific sets of operating system packages. Installation of third-party applications is not supported with 5G Network Slicing IAS, unless explicitly approved by Ciena. For example, third-party applications include antivirus, monitoring scripts, applications that write into file system etc.
Ensure your server meets the requirements and firewall ports are open
Download the files you need for installation
Perform tasks required to be done before setting up hosts and installing the solution
Setup hosts and install 5G Network Slicing IAS
Setup and configure hosts, set up licenses, and install the solution
Perform tasks such as verifying the installation, on-boarding the 3GPP plugin, creating a 5G Super slice
This section discusses the server hardware and virtual machine (VM) requirements to install the Blue Planet 5G Network Slicing IAS.
Requirements are based on the following two environments:
Contact your Ciena account representative if you have questions about server requirements.

The following table lists all the resources and their specifications you must follow while installing either 5G Network Slicing IAS or one of the solutions that is a combination of one or more Blue Planet products.
Values of the following items are common for all the installation scenarios.
Table 2. 5G Network Slicing IAS server requirements
16 GB (for hosts with up to 64 GB
In order for HA to function properly, it is required that:

The following table shows the recommended server disk space allocations based on total disk space recommended in Table 2 and 3. Mount the file systems with the standard options. However, /home must allow the 5G Network Slicing IAS installer to execute.
Table 3. Recommended 5G Network Slicing IAS server disk space allocations
Logging from applications and services to syslog
Scales based on number of 5G Network Slicing IAS domains, services, resources, events, and other entities
(defaults to the unallocated disk space in the root volume group)
The ports listed in the following table must be open to allow communication among 5G Network Slicing IAS hosts and components. Ports include:
Table 4. 5G Network Slicing IAS required open ports
DNS client—Allows the Blue Planet server to resolve names.
DHCP client (optional)—Allows the Blue Planet server to get IP addresses through DHCP.
NTP client—Used to set the time on the Blue Planet server.
SNMP server—Used for Blue Planet server monitoring.
SSH server—Used for Blue Planet server administrative access.
HTTP — Enables data transmission in plain text.
HTTPS — Enables data transmission over a secured network.
Generic Routing Encapsulation (GRE) tunnel between hosts. For host-to-host connectivity over GRE, IP connectivity must be available. TCP or UDP ports are not required.
A web browsing port primarily used for HTTP service, which provides enables data transmission in plain text.
A web browsing port primarily used for HTTPS service, which provides encryption and transport over secure ports.

Before you install your Blue Planet software, make sure you have the licenses you need. You need a license to extract the software from the tar files you downloaded from the Ciena portal, and you need licenses to run the software application and add-ons.
During the License Server setup procedure, you will associate the licenses with your license server and load the licenses.
The following tables list the licenses to extract the software and to run the software application.
For more information about the product licenses, contact the Blue Planet customer support.

To install 5G Network Slicing IAS, download the following files:

Many factors can affect download speed including internet connection throughput and other variables. If you cancel or lose your connection, you must start the download process again.
If the checksum does not match the value recorded in step 8c, download the file again and repeat this step. Otherwise, continue with the next step.
5G Network Slicing IAS requires one of the following operating systems with the Infrastructure Server package:

During the OS installation, you choose options that facilitate the installation and operations. If the OS is already installed, review the installation steps to ensure the selected options are provisioned on your host. If you have any questions, contact Ciena Customer Support.
All hosts where you will install the OS meet the requirements listed in the

Before you install Blue Planet 5G Network Slicing IAS, perform the following procedures on host 0 in sequence. For multihost installations, you do not need to repeat these procedures on other hosts unless specified in the procedure.
The following table provides an overview to the pre-installation procedures, where you perform them, and key notes.
Table 7. 5G Network Slicing IAS pre-installation procedures

The bpadmin user is given full passwordless sudo privileges. For multi-host installations, use the same bpadmin password on all hosts. The bpadmin user with full sudo access is needed to install the 5G Network Slicing IAS applications and to create the bpuser, which has limited sudo access.
Complete the following procedure to create the bpadmin user on each host where you will install 5G Network Slicing IAS. This is a mandatory procedure.
Before you begin, ensure that you have a password that you want to assign for the bpadmin user.
Set the password for the bpadmin user:
For multi-host deployments, repeat this procedure on each host. Use the same bpadmin password on all hosts.
After you complete the 5G Network Slicing IAS installation, you can optionally delete the bpadmin user and use bpuser for ongoing Docker, solman, and bp2-site operations.
To configure the swappiness kernal parameter:
Reload the system control. This should return a 10 value.
For multi-host installations, complete steps 1-4 at each host.

header: Host setup and 5G Network Slicing IAS installation

content.text: To install Blue Planet 5G Network Slicing IAS, perform the following procedures on host 0 in sequence. For multi-host installations, you do not need to repeat these procedures on other hosts unless specified in the procedure.
content.header: Host setup and 5G Network Slicing IAS installation

content.text: The following table provides an overview to the installation procedures, where you perform them, and key notes.
content.header: Host setup and 5G Network Slicing IAS installation

content.text: Table 8. 5G Network Slicing IAS installation procedures
content.header: Host setup and 5G Network Slicing IAS installation
Host setup and 5G Network Slicing IAS installation

content.text: Complete this procedure to add the host(s) where you want to install 5G Network Slicing IAS to the hosts file. This is a mandatory procedure.
If your installation is multiple hosts, complete following steps.

Uncomment and set one host entry (for each host) to the IP address for that host. Use the host IP address of each host (IPv4, not IPv6), not the hostname. Set controller=True (the default) for up to three hosts, then controller=False for remaining hosts.
All cluster hosts must be on the same subnet.
Uncomment and set the site IP variable to an IP address and subnet mask for the cluster. The site IP must be an IP address on the same subnet as the host IP addresses.
Optionally, uncomment the site_name entry and replace <mysite> with your site name. Valid characters are letters, numbers, and dashes.

site_name allows you to associate a meaningful name to the cluster. It is not required for normal 5G Network Slicing IAS operations, apart from certain Blue Planet microservices, such as Message Relay. Allowed characters are the same as hostnames, that is, a-z, A-Z, 0-9, and dashes.
Leave server_type set at the default, "customer". Other options including internal to Ciena are:
The following shows a sample active host file after the multi-host edits are made for an installation where the subnet mask is 22 (255.255.252.0):
host0 ansible_host=10.186.0.1 controller=True host1 ansible_host=10.186.0.2 controller=True host2 ansible_host=10.186.0.3 controller=True
If you want to install the solution on the same cluster, complete following steps:
Ensure that the hosts file contains six hosts.

Uncomment and set one host entry (for each host) to the IP address for that host. Use the host IP address of each host (IPv4, not IPv6), not the hostname. Set controller=True (the default) for up to three hosts, then controller=False for remaining hosts.
For the last three hosts, which are dedicated for BPI, add a solution label and provide a comma separated list of solution.
All cluster hosts must be on the same subnet.
Uncomment and set the site IP variable to an IP address and subnet mask for the cluster. The site IP must be an IP address on the same subnet as the host IP addresses.
Optionally uncomment the site_name entry and replace <mysite> with your site name. Valid characters are letters, numbers, and dashes.

site_name allows you to associate a meaningful name to the cluster. It is not required for normal 5G Network Slicing IAS operations, apart from certain Blue Planet microservices, such as Message Relay. Allowed characters are the same as hostnames, that is, a-z, A-Z, 0-9, and dashes.
Leave server_type set at the default, "customer". Other options including internal to Ciena are:
The following shows a sample active host file after the multi-host edits are made for an installation where the subnet mask is 22 (255.255.252.0):

[cluster] host0 ansible_host=10.186.34.35 controller=True host1 ansible_host=10.186.34.94 controller=True host2 ansible_host=10.186.33.135 controller=True host3 ansible_host=10.186.32.38 controller=False solution=bpinvsolutionst,bpinvcustartifactsst host4 ansible_host=10.186.34.239 controller=False solution=bpinvsolutionst,bpinvcustartifactsst host5 ansible_host=10.186.34.224 controller=False solution=bpinvsolutionst,bpinvcustartifactsst [cluster:vars] site_ip=10.186.0.4/22 site_name=BPSite1
Use the volume group name to restore data on another system. Ciena recommends using unique names that can be recognized and avoid name conflicts across multiple virtual groups.

Complete this procedure to modify the volume group name where the unallocated physical extents space is left free for 5G Network Slicing IAS to create and configure the Docker thin pool. This procedure is needed if you want to change the default values.
Before you begin, verify that you know the name of the volume group where the unallocated physical extents space is available for 5G Network Slicing IAS to create and configure the Docker thin pool.
To modify the volume group name:
5G Network Slicing IAS hosts can use a local or remote time source. For example:
By default, the Blue Planet installer sets up four NTP servers:

While you can specify your own NTP servers, or use fewer servers, Ciena recommends that you always have a minimum of three—and preferably four—timing servers for optimal 5G Network Slicing IAS timing synchronization. The number of upstream servers, in order of most to least preferred, is given below.
Disable all other timing synchronization methods including, but not limited to, VMware Tools periodic time synchronization.
Following installation, you can use the bp2-site check-platform or bp2-site check-clock-drift commands to check 5G Network Slicing IAS timing synchronization.
Complete this procedure to configure the Network Time Protocol (NTP) server(s) to serve as the timing source for 5G Network Slicing IAS hosts. This is a mandatory procedure.

All 5G Network Slicing IAS hosts must be synchronized to an accurate timing source. If you want to use a local time source or custom remote time sources (different than the default ones provided), then perform this procedure.
To use custom remote time sources, uncomment and edit the
list to include the NTP server URLs or IP addresses that you want used as the 5G Network Slicing IAS host timing source.
the edit for the custom remote time sources. The example focuses on the section to be edited.

header: Configuring the Blue Planet email service

content.text: 5G Network Slicing IAS requires that you configure a Simple Mail Transfer Protocol (SMTP) server, so 5G Network Slicing IAS can send system email to users. Emails are used for alarm notifications and forgotten password assistance.
content.header: Configuring the Blue Planet email service

content.text: If password expirations are enabled and the SMTP server is not configured, users will not be able to log in after their password expires. Ciena recommends if you cannot complete the configuration now, ensure you do it within 60 days to avoid causing users to be locked out with no way to reset their passwords.
Complete the following procedure to configure Blue Planet email service. This is a mandatory procedure.
Before you begin, verify that you understand the SMTP server requirements at your site.
To configure the Blue Planet email service:
# SMTP configuration details for 'Forgot Password' feature
# SMTP configuration details for 'Forgot Password' feature
5G Network Slicing IAS uses the address, 172.16.0.0/16/24, for its internal LAN (iLAN).
Complete this procedure if your network already uses 172.16.0.0/16/24, in which case, a conflict with the 5G Network Slicing IAS iLAN will occur.
Before you begin, verify that you have a new address for the iLAN.
# The ilannet to use on hosts
# The ilannet to use on hosts

Complete this procedure to manage keys of the bpadmin user and the root user, and to create the bpuser user (sudo restricted Docker install user) and manage its sudo permissions and keys. This is a mandatory procedure. The setup script skips this step if you have previously manually created the bpuser user.
Before you begin, verify that you know the bpadmin user password and the password you want to assign to the bpuser.
The validation phase checks the following areas and related requirements:
To validate the hardware and software:
The system displays various task-related outputs as the validation progresses. At the end of the validation process, the system displays a summary.
If elements display a Failed status, correct them, then repeat step 2 until all elements display a Passed status.
Configuring the 5G Network Slicing IAS host(s) creates the following directories and ensures they are owned by bpuser:

Complete the following procedure to configure the 5G Network Slicing IAS host(s) for the 5G Network Slicing IAS software installation. This is a mandatory procedure. This procedure also performs minor configuration changes including updates to syslog, rsyslog, sshd, and NTP to prepare the host for 5G Network Slicing IAS installation.
Output, similar to the following, indicates whether the configuration succeeded:
If no failures occur, indicated by failed=0, continue with the next step. If failures occurred, contact Ciena Customer Support for guidance.

content.text: After you have completed the installation of 5G Network Slicing IAS, complete the following steps:
Post line-up installation, Neo4j database scripts take 60 to 90 mins complete. Navigate to the following log file to check the status of Neo4j database scripts:
Output similar to the following, indicates whether the execution of the Neo4j database scripts completed:
After you deploy 5G Network Slicing IAS successfully, you must onboard a 3rd Generation Partnership Project (3GPP) plugin. Onboarding a 3GPP plugin requires you to:
The 3GPP is an umbrella term for a number of standards organizations which develop protocols and standards for mobile telecommunications.

To view whether the plugin is onboarded successfully, on the API Controller page, in the plugins section, execute the Get /plugins API operation, which shows a list of all onboarded plugins in the Response body; for example:
1. Log in to Blue Planet Application Bar.
After the 3GPP plugin is onboarded, create a 5G super slice to load the default service specifications.
Once you create a super slice, you can perform any slice specific operation using the 5G Network Slicing IAS UI.

diskutil list sudo dd if=rhel-server-7.7-x86_64-dvd.iso of=/dev/disk4 bs=4096
Set the password for the bpadmin user.
Assign the bpadmin user full sudo privileges.
Verify that you can use the sudo command without entering a password.
Reload the system control. This should return a 10 value.
where, <profile> is the validation profile. Possible values are: orch-dev (lab environment) or orch-prod (production environment).

content.text: Complete this procedure to uninstall the 5G Network Slicing IAS software, optionally fix a reversible site configuration issue such as a misconfigured ILAN NET interface, and re-install the 5G Network Slicing IAS software. .
The four main phases of the installation workflow are:
When you uninstall the 5G Network Slicing IAS software, you undo phase 4 (installation) of the installation workflow. Phases 1 to 3 remain complete.
